answer:
Tip #1: Plan Ahead

Planning ahead can help you stick to your diet. Pack healthy snacks and plan your meals in advance so you're prepared when cravings strike. Here are a few tips to get you started:

• Pack healthy snacks. Instead of reaching for junk food when cravings hit, try to pack healthy snacks ahead of time. Fresh fruit, raw veggies, or homemade energy balls can help satisfy your sweet tooth. You can also try making a batch of healthy trail mix.

• Plan your meals. Plan your meals in advance so you'll have healthy options ready to go. It can help you avoid ordering takeout or buying convenience foods on your way home.

• Make a grocery list. Make a list of the foods you need and stick to it when shopping. It can help you avoid impulse buys and make healthier choices.

Tip #2: Find Healthy Alternatives
Instead of reaching for junk food when cravings hit, try finding healthy alternatives. Fresh fruit, raw veggies, or homemade energy balls can help satisfy your sweet tooth. You can also try making a batch of healthy trail mix. Here are a few tips to help you find healthy alternatives:

• Keep healthy snacks on hand. Instead of reaching for junk food when cravings hit, try to keep healthy snacks on hand. You can pack your own snacks, or keep healthy options like fruit, raw veggies, and nuts in your desk or at work.

• Make healthy recipes ahead of time. Prepare a batch of healthy homemade trail mix or energy balls so you'll have them on hand when cravings strike. You can also try making a batch of healthy cookies or muffins ahead of time.

• Keep healthy ingredients on hand. Keep healthy ingredients like fruits, nuts, and veggies on hand so you'll have them when you need them. You can also keep healthy snacks like raw veggies and hummus in your desk so you can reach for them when you need a quick healthy snack.

Tip #3: Stay Hydrated
Sometimes cravings can be a sign of thirst. Try drinking water before reaching for food, and keep a water bottle with you throughout the day. Here are a few tips to help you stay hydrated:

• Drink a glass of water before eating. Drinking a glass of water before reaching for food can help curb your appetite and make it easier to stick to your diet.

• Keep a water bottle with you. Keep a water bottle on your desk or in your bag so you'll have it when you need it. You can also keep one in your fridge so you'll be more likely to drink it when you're thirsty.

• Set reminders. Set reminders on your phone or computer to drink water throughout the day. You can also use an app like Hydration to track your water intake and set reminders.

prompt: How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
answer:
When you buy stock in a company, you become part-owner of that company. You are now a shareholder, and as a shareholder, you are entitled to certain rights and protections. The company is now obligated to treat you fairly, and in some cases, you can even vote on important issues, such as the composition of the Board of Directors. In exchange for this, you pay money to the company and are entitled to a portion of the company's profits, or dividends. When the company does well, and profits are distributed to shareholders, you, as a shareholder, will receive a portion of those profits in the form of dividends.

The stock market is where shareholders buy and sell stock in companies, and where companies go to raise money in order to grow their businesses. When a company wants to raise money, it sells stocks to investors. When an investor wants to buy stock, they buy stock from another investor. This is how money goes from your pocket into the stock market, and how it is used to support the businesses you've bought stock in.

prompt: Explain me the Finite Elemente Method
answer:
The Finite Element Method or FEM is a numerical method for solving problems of solid mechanics. It is a powerful tool used in finite element analysis (FEA) to analyze stress and strain in structural members and internal stresses in parts subjected to complex loading conditions. It is frequently used in the analysis of structures and mechanical systems such as bridges, buildings, machinery, and vehicle components. The method is also used in the design of new products and structures, and in the evaluation of existing products and structures.

The Finite Element Method is based on dividing the problem domain into a finite number of elements. Each element is represented by a boundary polygon and a finite set of nodes that represent the degree of freedom (DoF) of the element. The FEA model is constructed by assembling a set of elements that represent the geometry and properties of the structure being analyzed. The model may be 2D or 3D depending on the problem. The FEA model is solved by iteratively applying loads to the model and solving for the resulting displacements at the nodes. Displacements are then used to calculate the stresses in the model. The displacement is then used to determine the response of the structure.

prompt:
Title: "Inspiration, Infallibility, and Inerrancy: Hath God Said? with R.C. Sproul - YouTube"
Video Transcript: "SPROUL: Any time the subject of the authority of Scripture is raised and people engage in discussions about it, there are three pivotal concepts that inform the conversation. Those concepts, I’ll write on the board, and then we’ll take some time to define them. They include the concept of inspiration, the concept of infallibility, and the concept of inerrancy. Now, before I go into a development of these concepts here, I’d like you to just think within the quiet chambers of your own mind, what are your personal reactions to these concepts? What do you think of when you hear the word inspiration, and what goes through your mind when you think of the term infallible? And perhaps most importantly, how do you react viscerally to the term inerrant, or inerrancy? I ask these questions for a reason. There is a tremendous amount of emotion that casts a pall over each and all of these terms, and sometimes I find it in theology somewhat difficult for people to get past the emotion to examine carefully the content that is contained in these words. F or example, when I was in... in seminary, if somebody used the term inerrancy with respect to the Scripture that immediately categorized that person as being a back woods fundamentalist with no education whatsoever. The normal response would be, “How could anybody believe in the inerrancy of Scripture in this day and age after two hundred years of profound academic analysis and scholarly criticism?” And so, the term inerrancy emerges something of a shibboleth. As a word that became a passport for orthodoxy or opposed to orthodoxy, and so on. This issue became so severe that in the late seventies an organization was formed in America that included scholars from around the world. Several hundred of them as a matter of fact, but under the leadership of an executive committee of fifteen or sixteen of them to study the question of the authority, the inspiration, the infallibility, the inerrancy of the Bible. And this organization was called the International Council on Biblical Inerrancy. And it devoted itself not only to ten years of study, but also of publications of various sorts and several conferences. And the first summit meeting of this organization was held in Chicago in 1978 when several hundred people came together and discussed and debated various issues about the integrity of Scripture. And what emerged from that event was a document that included a united statement on Scripture and then, a lengthier document that included affirmations, twenty-some affirmations and denials about Scripture. That is, careful definitions saying, “We affirm that the Bible is this, this, and this. We deny that it is this, this, and this.” So that it would be as clear as possible what was being stated on the matter. I was asked to write a commentary for the ICBI event on that document of affirmations and denials, and in brief form, so that the lay person could have it, and read through it and be educated and informed about some of these very subtle questions regarding sacred Scripture. prompt: Introduce the ”financial markets and institutions“ by Frederic S. Mishkin
answer:
Financial markets and institutions refers to the markets and the institutions through which financial assets are traded, and the processes through which financial intermediaries raise funds. Financial markets are made up of two types of participants: borrowers and lenders. Borrowers want to fund their operations by borrowing money, while lenders want to earn a return on their capital. Financial institutions, such as banks, bond dealers, and investment banks, match these borrowers and lenders and facilitate the flow of funds between them.

The financial system consists of an interconnected network of financial markets and institutions. The markets are the physical facilities where transactions take place, and the institutions include banks, brokerage firms, mutual funds, and investment banks. The financial system links borrowers and lenders together and facilitates efficient allocation and pricing of financial assets.

prompt: what are five important topics for game design
answer:
The five most important topics for game design are:

1. Game design principles: The first topic of importance is game design principles. These are fundamental concepts that are used by game designers to develop their games. Some examples of game design principles include:

* Player agency: This concept emphasizes that the player should have control over the game at all times and be able to make decisions that influence the game world.
* Emergent gameplay: This concept emphasizes that the gameplay of a game should be influenced by the player's actions and not scripted by the game designer.
* Flow: This concept emphasizes that players should be able to progress through the game easily and have a sense of accomplishment while doing so.
* Player retention: This concept emphasizes that players should want to continue playing the game after completing it.
* Fun: This concept emphasizes that a game should be entertaining and enjoyable for the player.

2. Player psychology: The second topic of importance is player psychology. This concept emphasizes that the player's behavior in the game should be influenced by their psychology. Some examples of player psychology include:

* Flow: This concept emphasizes that players should feel a sense of progress and accomplishment while playing the game.
* Fear: This concept emphasizes that players should feel apprehensive or nervous while playing the game.
* Competition: This concept emphasizes that players should feel competitive or competitive urges while playing the game.

3. Game mechanics: The third topic of importance is game mechanics. This concept emphasizes that the game's mechanics should be designed in such a way that they support the game's objectives. Some examples of game mechanics include:

* Combat: This concept emphasizes that players should be able to engage in fighting and combat in the game.
* Exploration: This concept emphasizes that players should be able to explore the game world and discover the game's secrets.
* Economy: This concept emphasizes that the game's economy should be well-designed and make sense within the game world.

4. Game aesthetics: The fourth topic of importance is game aesthetics. This concept emphasizes that the game's visuals and graphics should be designed in such a way that they support the game's objectives. Some examples of game aesthetics include:

* Atmosphere: This concept emphasizes that the game's visuals and sound design should create an immersive and atmospheric experience for the player.
* Worldbuilding: This concept emphasizes that the game's visuals and story should build an interesting world for the player to explore and interact with.
* Color theory: This concept emphasizes that the game's visuals and color palette should be designed in such a way that they support the game's objectives.

5. Game design theory: The fifth and final topic of importance is game design theory. This concept emphasizes that game designers should stay up-to-date with the latest developments and trends in the field of game design. Some examples of game design theory include:

* Player-centered design: This concept emphasizes that the game should be designed around the player's experience and not around the designer's vision.
* Design patterns: This concept emphasizes that game designers should use common techniques and patterns to create their games.
* Game design documentation: This concept emphasizes that game designers should document their game design processes and final designs.

6. Game design tools: The sixth topic of importance is game design tools. This concept emphasizes that game designers should use the right tools to create their games. Some examples of game design tools include:

* Game engines: This concept emphasizes that game designers should use game engines to create their games. Some examples of game engines include:
  * Unity: This game engine is used to create 3D games for PC, consoles, and mobile devices.

prompt: assume the persona of a therapist and walk me through how to be less reactive and use a pause ritual
answer:
The key to reacting less and responding more is to use a pause ritual. Before you respond to someone, take a moment to breathe and pause. Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths, focusing on the inhale and the exhale. This will help you slow down and process what you are feeling, rather than reacting to the situation in the moment.

Next, notice your body and your breath. Are you feeling tense or stressed? What sensations are you feeling in your body? Are you experiencing any physical changes? Are you sweating, trembling, or feeling your heart race? Paying attention to what is happening in your body can help you become more aware of your emotions and how you are responding to a situation.

Once you have calmed down, you can use a pause ritual to respond to the situation. A pause ritual is a mindfulness technique that gives you a moment to reflect, think, and consider how you want to respond to a situation. You can use any type of ritual that works for you, such as taking a few deep breaths, closing your eyes, or focusing on your breathing. The key is to use a ritual that helps you to relax and slow down.

Once you have calmed down, you can take a moment to think about what you want to say or do. The goal is to use a pause, rather than a response, to help you make a more considered decision. The pause ritual gives you a moment to step back and think about the situation, rather than reacting in the moment.

Next, take a moment to choose how you want to respond to the situation. Do you want to respond in a way that is assertive, collaborative, or non-confrontational? How do you want to communicate your feelings and needs to the other person? The key is to choose a response that respects the other person and their feelings, and that helps you to feel calm and in control of the situation. If the other person is not being respectful, it may be helpful to use an assertive response to let them know you will not tolerate their behavior.

Finally, take a moment to say or do whatever you have decided is the most appropriate response. This could be telling the other person that you are upset, asking for an apology, explaining how you are feeling, or expressing what you need. The goal is to respond in a way that respects the other person and helps you to feel calm and in control of the situation.

If you find that you are still experiencing strong emotions, you may want to take a few more moments to relax and calm down. You can use a pause ritual, such as taking a few deep breaths, closing your eyes, or focusing on your breathing, to help you calm down and feel more in control of your emotions. If your emotions continue to escalate, it may be helpful to take a break from the situation and come back to it at a later time.

prompt: In order to launch a token for a Defi project, I want to sell some tokens privately to early investors and then add it to a launchpad. let me know what can I do with my smart contract? Should I create a presale contract separate from main contract?
answer:
There are two options for selling tokens to early investors:

 1. Token sale via a pre-sale contract and a launchpad

A pre-sale contract gives early investors the opportunity to buy your tokens at a discounted price. This can be done via public or private sales, depending on your preference. The sale can be launched from the Defi Foundation Launchpad, a publicly-accessible platform for launching and managing token sales.

2. Token sale via a presale contract and an initial coin offering (ICO)

An ICO is a fundraising event where participants purchase tokens with crypto or fiat. You can launch an ICO directly from the Defi Foundation Launchpad.

Both options can be used together as well: You can launch a pre-sale on the Defi Foundation Launchpad and then follow-up with an ICO to give investors the opportunity to buy tokens at a lower price.

If you are unsure about the best option for you, the Defi Foundation team can help you choose the most suitable path for your project.

prompt: what are some basics of nutrition that i should be aware of
answer:
The Basics of Nutrition

Nutrition is the process of supplying the body with food, water, and other nutrients to support normal cellular function and growth. Nutrients can be consumed through food or drink or obtained through supplements. These nutrients provide the body with energy and the necessary building blocks to support bodily functions like digestion, cellular repair, immune function, and more.

Food provides the body with the essential macronutrients such as carbohydrates, protein, and fat. These macronutrients are broken down and metabolized into energy to fuel the body. Macronutrients are also needed to support the growth and repair of bodily tissues.

Food also provides the body with important micronutrients, or vitamins and minerals. These vitamins and minerals are necessary for various bodily functions such as bone health, muscle function, and hormone regulation. Micronutrients can be found in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and seeds. Vitamins and minerals can also be consumed in supplement form.

A healthy diet consists of a balance of macronutrients and micronutrients to support the body's needs. A balanced diet provides the body with the energy and nutrients needed to support proper cellular function, growth, and repair.

prompt:
question about Computer architecture and organization 
for 6 marks
what in general terms is the distinction between computer organization and computer architecture ?
give answer in full sentence points if possible
answer: The distinction between computer organization and computer architecture is a fundamental one in computer science. Computer organization is the physical layout of a computer system, and it includes such things as the location of input and output devices such as keyboards and monitors, the location of memory devices such as RAM and ROM, and the location of the CPU and other processing elements. Computer architecture refers to the logical design and operation of a computer. It includes things like the number of bits in a byte, the number of bits in a register, the number of instructions that can be executed per cycle, and the overall organization of programs and data. Computer architecture is often described as the "instruction set architecture" or ISA of a computer, and it is the ISA that determines the instruction set for a particular processor.

prompt: what are african governments doing to improve air traffic connectivity
answer:
The African Union Commission (AUC) together with the African Civil Aviation Commission (AFCAC) have developed a 10-year strategic plan, known as the 2020 Flight Plan, to guide the development of the aviation industry in Africa and to address challenges hampering the development of the industry.

The implementation of the Flight Plan has been divided into six phases.

The 1st phase (2015 – 2019) focused on the development of the aviation infrastructure through airport development and expansion; upgrading and strengthening of the air navigation systems; and developing the aviation human resources.

The 2nd phase (2016 – 2020) prioritised the development of the aviation regulatory framework in order to enhance the safety and security of the air transport industry; and the development of the aviation industry through the promotion of the market and facilitating the integration of the industry.

The 3rd phase (2020 – 2025) will focus on the promotion of the market and facilitating the integration of the industry.

The 4th phase (2025 – 2030) will build on the foundation laid in the first three phases with a focus on regional integration by facilitating the development of air transport corridors to improve connectivity and promote tourism.

The 5th phase (2030 – 2050) will focus on implementing the Africa’s Single Air Transport Market in order to achieve seamless intra-African connectivity, as well as connecting Africa to the World.

prompt: #2. To increase the energy efficiency of windows, additional glass pane is added. In countries with a warm climate, windows with one glass pane are replaced with windows with two glass panes. Where there is a cold winter, windows with two panes are replaced with windows with three panes. Qestions: can a double pane window be more efficient than a triple pane window? Can a single pane window be more efficient than a double pane window? If yes, what is needed for this? Support your answer with appropriate calculations.
answer:
A double pane window can be more energy efficient than a triple pane window, but the difference is not as great as one might expect. A single pane window can be more energy efficient than a double pane window, but this requires more insulation.

For example, assume a double pane window with a total thickness of 1 inch has an R-value of 5.1/inch = 25.2 and a single pane window has an R-value of 2.4/inch = 5.7. In this example, a single pane window (5.7) has a higher R-value than a double pane window (25.2).

However, the double pane window has a smaller U-factor (0.34 W/m2K) than the single pane window (0.41 W/m2K). The lower U-factor of the double pane window means less heat flow through the window, which is the main reason that the double pane window is more energy efficient.

In summary, a double pane window with a higher R-value can be more energy efficient than a triple pane window, but not as much as one might expect. In contrast, a single pane window can be more energy efficient than a double pane window, but this requires more insulation.

prompt: Write a poem about Mike and Joe becoming millionaires by leveraging the power of AI to become the greatest Agile coaches in history. Include content from the agile manifesto.
answer:
Once upon a time, two brothers named Mike and Joe were born. They grew up in the mountains of Colorado where they learned to ski. As children, they dreamed of becoming ski instructors and living in the mountains. When they grew up, they became ski instructors. They worked hard, but after a few years, they realized they didn't enjoy spending their lives in the cold mountains. They wanted to travel and explore the world. They wanted to help others live happier and healthier lives. They wanted to work with cutting-edge technology, and they wanted to work in the city. They knew their skills as ski instructors would only take them so far, and they needed to learn something new.

Mike and Joe read an article about Agile. They were fascinated by the idea of working in an environment that promoted creativity and collaboration. They knew they had the skills to help organizations implement Agile and become more productive, but they didn't know how to get started. They had never worked in an Agile environment before, and they didn't know anyone who had. They didn't know what the steps were, and they didn't know where to begin.

Mike and Joe decided to start their own company to help organizations become more Agile. They knew they needed to learn everything they could about Agile, and they knew they needed to learn about Agile coaching. They both loved skiing, so they decided to name their company Snow Agile. Mike and Joe spent the next few years learning and practicing Agile. They read books and took classes. They practiced Agile with their own teams and with the teams of their clients. They coached their clients' teams in Agile and helped them improve their Agile maturity. They learned from their experiences, and they learned from their clients' experiences.

Snow Agile became well-known in the Agile community. People knew Mike and Joe were Agile experts, and organizations hired them to help them with their Agile transformations. Mike and Joe were excited about the work they were doing, and they were proud that their company was successful. They were passionate about helping teams become more Agile and about helping organizations become more productive. They were happy to be working in the city instead of living in the mountains, and they were happy to be working with cutting-edge technology. They were living the dream, and they were excited about the future.

Mike and Joe's company grew, and they hired more Agile coaches to help them with their work. They were now Agile experts, and they had become millionaires by leveraging the power of AI. Mike and Joe lived happy and healthy lives, and they worked with teams all over the world. They traveled to different countries, helped organizations become more productive, and helped teams become more Agile. They never stopped learning, and they were always growing and improving as coaches and as Agile practitioners. Mike and Joe were the greatest Agile coaches in history, and they had become millionaires by leveraging the power of AI.

prompt: Rewrite the given introductory paragraph so that it starts with a pertinent anecdote. Also rewrite the thesis so that it is succinct and concise:    "Many types of black people have different cultural backgrounds and experiences. For example, African and African American cultures share a common ancestry and history of struggles but have distinct cultural identities. While both groups are considered Black, they have different experiences, records, and cultural practices. As Saint Augustine said, “The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page.” This quote emphasizes the importance of exploring other cultures to understand their experiences better. As I have gotten older, I have come to understand the similarities and differences between these two individuals."
answer:
Many types of black people have different cultural backgrounds and experiences. For example, African and African American cultures share a common ancestry and history of struggles but have distinct cultural identities. While both groups are considered Black, they have different experiences, records, and cultural practices. As Saint Augustine said, “The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page.” This quote emphasizes the importance of exploring other cultures to understand their experiences better. As I have gotten older, I have come to understand the similarities and differences between these two individuals.

Both African American and African cultures have a rich history of overcoming oppression and resistance. The first African slaves were brought to the United States in the 1600s, and they began to establish communities in the American South. After slavery was abolished in 1865, African Americans faced racial discrimination and segregation that severely limited their social and economic opportunities. African Americans fought back against racism throughout the civil rights movement, which resulted in important legislation such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Meanwhile, African countries gained independence from colonial rule in the 1960s and 1970s, but they continued to face economic problems and civil unrest. African Americans and Africans have also faced similar challenges associated with immigration, such as language barriers and discrimination. However, both groups have also fostered strong communities that celebrate their heritage and culture, including music, dance, and food traditions.

Despite their shared heritage, African American and African cultures have distinctive identities. African Americans are descended from enslaved Africans brought to the United States, while Africans are indigenous to the continent of Africa. African Americans have a long history in the United States, while Africans have only recently gained independence from colonial rule. Furthermore, African Americans have a unique culture that has been shaped by centuries of slavery and discrimination, while Africans have their own distinct cultural practices. While both groups have faced similar challenges, they have developed unique cultural practices and traditions to meet their needs. For example, African American and African cultures have distinctive music and dance traditions. African American music has been shaped by jazz, blues, and hip-hop, while African music includes genres like Afro-beat and reggae. Similarly, African American and African dance traditions have evolved to suit different needs and cultures. African American dances have roots in African and Caribbean traditions, while African dances tend to be celebratory and community-focused.

TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. It is a typed superset of JavaScript because it adds optional type declarations to JavaScript variables, functions, and objects. TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript because the code that compiles to plain JavaScript can contain type declarations. TypeScript is a typed language because the type declarations act as type checks, which ensures that the code always compiles and executes correctly. The type declarations are optional because the TypeScript compiler will accept and compile code that does not have type declarations.

TypeScript also adds optional type annotations to properties, methods, and functions. Type annotations are required when the variables, methods, and functions are used outside of the TypeScript environment. Type annotations are optional when the variables, methods, and functions are used inside of the TypeScript environment. TypeScript supports object-oriented programming by adding optional type annotations to classes, interfaces, and parameters. TypeScript also supports the creation of classes and interfaces. The TypeScript compiler can create and compile JavaScript files that contain classes and interfaces.

TypeScript has many similarities with JavaScript, but it has several differences. The main difference between TypeScript and JavaScript is that TypeScript is a typed language, while JavaScript is not. TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript, but JavaScript is not a superset of TypeScript. Another difference between TypeScript and JavaScript is that TypeScript is a compiled language, while JavaScript is not. TypeScript uses the JavaScript engine to compile and execute JavaScript, which means that JavaScript files can contain TypeScript code.

Duck typing is a programming paradigm that allows the creation of objects and classes in a dynamic and flexible way. Duck typing is used when it is not necessary to define the type of a variable or object. Duck typing is also known as dynamic typing or dynamic typing. Duck typing does not require type declarations or type annotations, which means that duck typing is a looser typing style than type-based typing.

Type-based typing requires type declarations and type annotations to identify and define the type of a variable, method, or function. Type-based typing is stricter and more restrictive than duck typing, because type-based typing requires type declarations and type annotations. Type-based typing uses strict type checking to identify and enforce the type of a variable, method, or function. Type-based typing enforces strict type checking, which means that the code must always be valid and always compile and execute correctly.

prompt:
Write up insights from the book Upstream by Dan Heath and the book’s application to a team of Social Workers at Visalia Unified School District that have the following job description:
Under the direction of an assigned supervisor, the School Social Worker will provide school-based mental health services at school sites. The School Social Worker will assess and define problems children may be experiencing with school attendance and performance, family interactions, social problems and school-community relations which interfere with the student’s ability and potential to obtain a satisfactory education; consult and assist parents, teachers and others concerned with the child and his family in planning appropriate strategies for the problem and to assure services are provided according to planned strategy. 
Typical Duties:
1.	Establish with the child and the family a milieu where personal, interpersonal and intrafamilial concerns may be openly shared and discussed.
2.	Consult and collaborate with school personnel to promote a school environment responsive to the needs of children.
3.	Serve as a catalyst to generate, enhance and facilitate the problem-solving process as it affects individuals, groups, institutions and systems.
4.	Serve as an intercessor for students and their family in dealing with community agencies and institutions and with the school system; serve as an intercessor for the school system in dealing with community agencies and institutions.
5.	Conduct mental health and ongoing individual therapy for students
6.	Collect, gather, sort and analyze data about students, parents, and the communities served by the District.
7.	Supervise on-going activities of social work interns from university programs.
8.	Participate in special programs such as the Foster Youth Program as assigned.
9.	Perform related duties as assigned.
Personal Characteristics: 
Should possess the personal characteristics generally recognized as essential for good public employees including integrity, initiative, emotional maturity, dependability, courtesy, good judgment and ability to work cooperatively with others. 
Position Qualifications: 
Knowledge of:   
Effective personal and academic counseling techniques and procedures; counseling theory, ethics and associated legal confidentiality requirements; laws regarding minors and child abuse reporting; applicable sections of the State Education Code and other applicable laws, rules and regulations related to assigned activities; normal and abnormal child behavior and development; behavior modification techniques and strategies; student assistance programs; community referral resources; diverse academic, socioeconomic, cultural, disability, and ethnic backgrounds of District students; interpersonal skills using tact, patience and courtesy; correct English usage, grammar, spelling, punctuation and vocabulary; record-keeping techniques.
Ability and Skills to: 
Provide counseling and guidance services to students; engage a broad network of partners committed to improving the future of all members of the community; make referrals to other community resources, support groups and social service agencies as appropriate; plan, prepare and conduct individual and group counseling sessions; read, interpret, apply and explain rules, regulations, policies and procedures; maintain current knowledge of program rules, regulations, requirements and restrictions; manipulate and configure data to 
form statistical analysis; set limits and personal boundaries for students; assist with curriculum development; complete work with many interruptions; analyze situations accurately and adopt an effective course of action; work independently with little direction; meet schedules and time lines; work confidentially with discretion; maintain records and prepare various reports, including confidential materials; establish and maintain cooperative and effective working relationships with others; maintain consistent, punctual and regular attendance; sit or stand for extended periods of time; walk around the campus; lift heavy objects weighing up to 50 pounds; exchange information with others; monitor student behavior. 
Certificate/License/Insurance Requirement:   
Valid California Driver’s License and proof of vehicle insurance required. Licensed as Clinical Social Worker or Associate Clinical Social Worker by the California Board of Behavioral Sciences is preferred. 
Experience:   
One year of experience working with “at-risk” students in an educational or social services setting is desired.   
Education:   
Master of Social Work Degree or PPS credential with master’s degree in a related field required.
answer: Upstream: How To Start An Upward Movement by Dan Heath is a book that provides a framework to help individuals and organizations move to a better place. The book addresses how to identify and overcome our own internal forces that prevent us from making progress and instead keep us stuck in a downstream movement. The authors use a metaphor of a river to illustrate how to make progress upstream and how to overcome the forces that keep us moving in a downstream direction. The book is divided into two parts. The first part provides an overview of how we can use the river metaphor to understand why we are where we are and how to move to a better place. The second part provides strategies for how to make progress upstream and overcome the forces that keep us moving in a downstream direction.

prompt: how are carbon fibers used in buildings
answer:
Carbon fibers have been used in a variety of structures and products in the last 50 years. They have been used in aerospace, automotive, and sports equipment, but have been increasingly used in construction since the mid-1990s. Carbon fiber has been used in building construction for several decades, but it has only recently seen an increase in popularity.

Carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) is a composite material comprising carbon fibers embedded in a polymer matrix, such as epoxy, vinyl ester, or polyester. CFRP is a high-strength, lightweight, and durable material, making it a popular choice for reinforcement in building materials. CFRP has been used in building construction since the 1960s with the development of the lightweight and strong FRP panel. FRP panels, which are usually made of fiberglass, have been used in building construction for decades due to their low weight, durability, and fire resistance.

In the 1990s, CFRP became increasingly popular as a building material due to its high strength-to-weight ratio and lightweight properties. CFRP panels are often utilized in high-performance buildings, such as schools, offices, and museums, due to their strength and energy efficiency. CFRP is also increasingly being used in residential construction as the price of CFRP materials drops and the benefits of CFRP panels become more widely known.

prompt: how much of a threat is climate change in the coming years, and what should we do to stop it?
answer:
Climate change is one of the most significant challenges of this generation, and it will impact virtually every aspect of our lives. It is already causing harm to people, communities, economies and our environment around the world, and it will continue to do so in the future. To address this threat, we need to act now and act together – both at the national and international levels. This is happening, but more is needed.

Leaders from around the world came together at the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris (COP21) to adopt the first-ever universal, legally binding global climate agreement. The Paris Agreement establishes a long-term global goal of keeping the rise in global average temperature well below 2 degrees Celsius and pursuing efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The Agreement also aims to strengthen the ability of countries to deal with the impacts of climate change and to adapt to climate change. It sets out a global action plan to put the world on track to achieve sustainable development and low greenhouse gas emissions and to adapt to the increasing impacts of climate change.

The Paris Agreement entered into force on 4 November 2016, less than a year after it was adopted, establishing a new era of international cooperation on climate change. As of 16 November 2016, 111 countries representing 72 per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions have signed the Agreement and 22 countries representing 41 per cent of global emissions have ratified it.

To achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, the world must undergo a fundamental transformation of the global economy. This transformation must be guided by the principles and provisions of the Agreement, including the goal of low greenhouse gas emissions, climate resilience, and the capacity for nations to adapt to the impacts of climate change.

The Agreement also provides a clear roadmap for achieving this transformation and sets out a series of short, medium and long-term goals for the 2020s, 2030s and 2050s. It establishes a clear framework for all countries to strengthen their national climate plans and to increase ambition over time, and sets a new global emissions reduction target for the 2020s. It also provides a system to track progress and to ensure that nations are living up to their commitments to reduce emissions and strengthen climate resilience.

The Paris Agreement is a landmark achievement, but it is not enough to address the scale and urgency of the climate challenge. We need to step up our collective ambition and action – to meet the goals of the Agreement, to achieve long-term decarbonisation, and to build climate resilience. This will require deep changes across all sectors of society and will require all countries, both developed and developing, to transform their economies and societies in the coming years.

The Agreement is a global framework, but action to address climate change must be taken at all levels. National governments have the primary responsibility to lead, coordinate and implement climate change policies, and to set long-term national targets to reduce emissions and adapt to the impacts of climate change. This includes setting and implementing national climate plans, known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs).

The Agreement also recognises the role of sub-national, regional and local governments, as well as all sectors of society, in addressing climate change. This includes engaging in planning, implementation, and review of climate change policies. To support these efforts, the Agreement provides a platform for governments, businesses and other stakeholders to work together to enhance climate resilience, support clean, low-carbon growth, and mobilise climate finance for climate action.

To achieve the goal of holding the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius, countries have agreed to mobilize and make available $100 billion annually by 2020 to address climate change through mitigation and adaptation measures. This includes a commitment to increase this amount substantially in the future. The Agreement provides a framework for public and private finance to support climate action, including the establishment of a Green Climate Fund (GCF) and a Technology Mechanism to support climate action.

Higher temperatures lead to higher levels of vibration, which in turn leads to more energy production. prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
answer: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that can affect many different areas of the body. It causes tiny clumps of cells to form in the body’s tissues, most often in the lungs, lymph nodes, or liver. The exact cause of sarcoidosis is unknown, but the disease tends to occur in places where the immune system is active, such as the lungs and lymph nodes. In the lungs, these clumps of cells are called granulomas, and they can lead to lung problems such as shortness of breath and coughing. Sarcoidosis can also cause other symptoms, such as eye problems, sores in the skin, and swelling of the liver or lymph nodes. This disease is rare, and most people with the condition have mild symptoms that may go away without treatment. In other cases, sarcoidosis can cause complications that can be treated. There is no cure for sarcoidosis, but there are treatments that can reduce symptoms and help manage the disease.

The year 2022 saw the growth of the ESG concept in the global economy. The global financial crisis of 2008-2009 and the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic have had a significant impact on the economy of the world, which has led to a growing interest in the ESG issue. The SDGs, which are part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, aim to end poverty, improve health and education, and reduce inequalities and environmental impact. The SDGs are a set of universal goals and targets for sustainable development, adopted by 193 United Nations member states. The goals have a global character and are of great importance for the development of an ESG-driven economy.

February - The World Economic Forum published the Global Risks Report 2022, which showed the main risks in the world in 2022, including geopolitical tensions, the spread of infectious diseases, environmental disasters, natural disasters and cyberattacks. It is important to note that the key risks that are considered by the World Economic Forum are closely associated with the ESG concept - they are related to climate change, biodiversity, and the economy.

March - The World Economic Forum published the Sustainable Development Impact Assessment (SDiA), according to which the global economy in 2022 will face a $ 24 trillion shortfall in meeting the SDG goals. This deficit will be caused by inadequate funding, climate change, and inadequate technology. The report notes that the global economy in 2022 will need $27.3 trillion in investment, while only $3.1 trillion will be invested. This $24 trillion shortfall will lead to a slowdown in the global economy, as well as an increase in unemployment, poverty and inequality. The report notes that the lack of investment in the economy will lead to a slowdown in global GDP growth from 2.3% in 2022 to 1.9% by 2030. In addition, the report notes that in 2022, 820 million people will be living in poverty, and 115 million more will be unemployed.

April - The United Nations announced the launch of the Sustainable Development Goals Fund (SDG Fund), which aims to promote the achievement of the SDGs by providing financial and technical support and building capacity in developing countries. The SDG Fund will be created by merging the funds of the United Nations Development Program, the United Nations Office for Project Services, and the United Nations Environment Program. The SDG Fund will have an annual budget of $ 3.6 billion and will be implemented on a multi-year basis from 2021 to 2024.

May - The European Union and the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) announced the creation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) Fund, which will be implemented in 14 countries in the EU. The fund will provide grants, technical assistance and training in order to help these countries achieve the SDGs by 2030. The SDG Fund will be implemented under the "Global Environment Facility" program, which is financed by the European Union. The total volume of the program is $ 120 million.

This will be the slowest rate of growth in the global economy since the global financial crisis of 2008-2009. prompt:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There’s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we’re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‘us,’ we’ve got a lot to say.
While you don’t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‘foundered’ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‘clinker’ than ‘beezer’? Or appreciating that ‘grand’ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
“I think it’s really important,” says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
“I think sometimes we’re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
“Often the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,” he continues.
“Slang as a sort of term that’s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
“We have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that’s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they’re really quite amazing things.”
“It’s a potentially massive term,” says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
“One of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
“But then you’ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he’s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
“It’s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.”
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we’re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
“It’s one of those things that if we go on holiday and you’re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‘yer ma’, or ‘yer man’ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don’t and can’t,” says Dr Ferguson.
“There’s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there’s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
“Sometimes we might get anxious that we’re using cliches, but we’re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.”
Think too of Line of Duty’s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn’t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
“That really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
“Sometimes we’ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.”
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
“I think it’s unfortunate that it’s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,” says Gail.
“It’s so frustrating but I think there’s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
“And it’s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It’s one dimension of what slang can do.”
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
“In many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
“We have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
“We are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‘potatoes’ that we have.
“Certain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that’s a real strength. I think there’s a variety there and there’s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don’t think we’ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.”
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‘boak’ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‘the messages’? My favourite slang word ‘hoke’ has an Ulster Scots origin. It’s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
“Often there’s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it’s bad language, or it doesn’t have a sense of value behind it,” says Dr Ferguson.
“But on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
“There are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it’s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you’re in the room.
“Whenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns’ To a Mouse and ‘wee, sleekit, cowrin, tim’rous beastie’ appears in the first line.
“This really electrifies him because the word ‘wee’ appears. It’s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it’s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
“I think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we’ve grown up with, we’re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there’s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don’t connect us.”
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we’re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland’s case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‘wee.’
“We all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it’s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we’re foundered,” says Dr Ferguson.
“One of our great words, and I think there’s a difference between the town and city where it’s ‘scunnered’ or ‘scundered’. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‘I am totally scunnered’ or ‘I am totally scundered’ about something. These are things that we should protect.”
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
“Yesterday’s slang term is today or the future’s commonly understood term for something,” she explains.
“I guess that’s how language changes and evolves, through its users. You’re getting a people’s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
“Every year I’m always interested to see what makes it into the OED — it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
“In 2022, ‘a chara’ entered the OED. So did ‘fluthered’, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‘gaslighter’ and ‘vaxxed’. It’s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we’re living through.”
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‘beauty’ of slang is that it’s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
“It often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,” he laughs.
“But there’s a there’s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They’re used in some circles and in some groups.
“We all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we’ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‘uni’ seems one of the obvious words to use because it’s been floating through media, but it’s loaded into everyday speech.
“Language is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we’re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.”
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they’re widely available for visitors to enjoy — on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
“I think it’s actually gotten more popular,” she says of the slang-adorned items.
“There’s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
“I think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.”
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we’re proud of the places we call home.
From ‘up to high doh’ coasters to ‘a wee bag’ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
“I knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast — 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,” explains Linzi.
“With the Americans coming over and they ask, ‘What’s “awk hiya love?”’ – which we have on our socks and mugs – once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they’re running around America with a pair of ‘awk hiya love’ socks on with people asking, ‘What’s awk?’
“It creates engagement in the shop and it’s probably why the shop is doing so well as it’s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
“It opens conversations which is brilliant.”
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‘alright big lad’ and customers still love ‘Ulster says yeooo!’ and ‘ats us nai’.
“Having tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,” continues Linzi.
“For the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There’s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.”
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
“I was always very conscious that it’s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it’s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it’s quite popular.
“It may not want to be a mug you’d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‘alright’ sock in a style that’s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you’re able to tie those two together then you’ve got a good product. It’s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.”
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
“I’m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,” says Gail. “Simple things like I’ll say ‘plaster’ and she’ll say ‘Band-aid,’ I’ll say ‘chips’ and she’ll say ‘fries’. He knows that he’s betwixt and between terms.
“Even things like ‘wee’ and ‘what’s the craic?’ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who’s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‘Well, hello, what’s the craic?’ Or even words like ‘scundered’ or ‘jammy,’ or ‘dead on,’ all these things that I say quite often.”"

prompt: How can I calculate the amount of variations on a 3x4 table?
answer: The 3x4 table is a rectangular table with three rows and four columns. The amount of variations the table can hold is the number of possible combinations of the three rows and four columns.
